Companies put up bonds to cover their cleanup costs in the event they go bankrupt, but the bonds they pay up front are almost never enough.
Right now in Wyoming, companies only have the pay $75,000 for all of their wells on private land.
Mark Watson is Wyoming's oil and gas supervisor.
He recently proposed new rules that double that to $150,000.
Some companies - it would be more than enough, and some companies - it wouldn't be enough to plug all their wells.
Companies are supposed to pay a second bond when the wells stop producing, but historically, that hasn't always happened.
During the coal-bed methane boom, large companies sold their wells and the responsibility for plugging them to smaller companies that didn't post the second bond before going under.
Watson says the new rule will help avoid a repeat of that situation.
One of the things we probably need to do a better job at is identifying companies that aren't solvent and identify them sooner than we did when the coal-bed play ended.
But that's not easy.
In the recent oil price crash, even some relatively big companies have gone bankrupt.
There is a way to ensure there's enough money for cleanup.
Make companies pay for it upfront.
But that's not on the table in Wyoming or anywhere else in the country.
